questions.text: A 24-yr-old man presents with an excessive desire for sexual intercourse. What is this called?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of satyriasis. 

Satyriasis refers to uncontrollable or excessive sexual desire (hypersexuality) in males. It is also known as Don Juanism. Don Juan is a legendary, fictional libertine who devoted his life to seducing women.

Other options: 

Option B: Frotteurism is a form of paraphilic disorder wherein the affected male achieves sexual gratification by rubbing his penis against the buttocks or other body parts of a fully clothed woman. 

Option C: Nymphomania refers to excessive sexual desire or hypersexuality in women. It is a form of sexual addiction. 

Option D: Sexual masochism is a form of paraphilia wherein the individual has sexual fantasies or urges that involve acts of being beaten, bound, or humiliated. It is more commonly seen in men.

questions.text: The HIV sentinel surveillance includes all of the following populations except ______________
questions.solution:
Sentinel surveillance of HIV is usually not done for STD clinic attendees.

Sentinel surveillance is used to augment the notification systems used in the surveillance of diseases.

Till 2012-13, STD sites were also included in the HIV sentinel surveillance but from 2014-15, these sites were entirely discontinued, since the STD data had significant biases.

The study population for HIV sentinel surveillance includes:

  • Female sex worker: Women who are engaged in consensual sex for money or payment in kind, as a means of livelihood in the last six months
  • Men who had anal or oral sex with a male partner in the last month.
  • Injection drug users: Men and women who use addictive substances or drugs for recreational or non-medical reasons, through injections, at least once in the last three months.
  • Transgender: Person whose identity does not conform unambiguously to conventional notions of male or female gender roles, but combines or moves between these.
  • Single male migrants: Single male, living at a place other than the place of usual residence without his spouse or family, for the purposes of work and visiting his home town at least once a year.
  • Long-distance truckers: Truckers who travel more than 800 km one way between source and destination.
  • A pregnant woman of age 15-49 years and attending the antenatal clinic for the first time.

questions.text: A child rescued from a trafficking ring is brought to the department of forensic medicine for age estimation. The X-ray image of the hand is shown below. What is the likely age of the child?
questions.solution:
The child's age is likely to be 13 years.

In the above X-ray image of the wrist and hand, all the carpal bones are seen. The lower epiphysis of the first metacarpal has not united with the shaft. This suggests that the age of the child is 12 to 15 years.

questions.text: All of the following agents act by intracellular receptors except for ________
questions.solution:
Insulin receptors belong to the trans-membrane enzyme-linked receptor class.

Transmembrane enzyme-linked receptors

  • Large extracellular ligand-binding domain connected through a single transmembrane helical peptide chain to an intracellular subunit having enzymatic property.
  • Enzyme on the cytosolic side is usually a protein kinase (tyrosine) or membrane-bound GC.

Physiological ligands for transmembrane enzyme-linked receptors:

(Most are Growth factors and chemokines)

  • Receptor tyrosine kinases
    • Growth factors e.g. PDGF, EGF, VEGF
    • Insulin
  • Membrane-bound GC:
    • Natriuretic peptides
  • Receptor serine-threonine kinases:
    • TGF-beta 

Thyroid hormones, vitamin D, and steroids act via intracellular receptors (Options A, B, and D).

Related Pearl: Classification of Hormones by Mechanism of Action

A) Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors

  • Cytoplasmic receptors
    • Steroids such as glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids and androgens
  • Nuclear receptors
    • Thyroid hormones
    • Vitamins A and D

B) Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors

  • GPCR - G protein-coupled receptors
    • Gs - stimulation of the 2nd messenger cAMP
      • Examples: ACTH, CRH, TSH, LH, FSH hCG, Catecholamines (β receptors), Vasopressin (V2 receptors), Secretin, Somatostatin, and Glucagon.
    • Gi - inhibition of the 2nd messenger cAMP
      • Examples: Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors), Acetylcholine (M2, M4), Somatostatin
    • Gq - The 2nd messenger is Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG Ca2+)
      • Examples: Parathyroid hormone, GnRH - Gonadotropin-releasing hormone, GHRH - Growth hormone releasing hormone, TRH, Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors), Vasopressin (V1 receptor), Gastrin, Cholecystokinin and Oxytocin.
    • cGMP as the 2nd messenger
      • Examples: Atrial natriuretic factor, Nitric oxide
  • Tyrosine kinase receptors such as those that employ Janus kinase (JAK-STAT pathway) or MAP kinase pathway
    • Growth hormone, Growth factors (GFs) - eg: IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF etc, Erythropoietin, Insulin and Prolactin.

Note: Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

questions.text: Identify the site marked in the image given below
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the sphenoid sinus. It drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

Paranasal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the bones of the skull. These paranasal sinuses have been divided into two groups:

Anterior group: It includes,

  • Maxillary sinus (Antrum of Highmore)
  • Frontal sinus
  • Anterior ethmoidal.

All of the above sinuses open into the middle meatus and their ostia lie anterior to the basal lamella of the middle turbinate.

Posterior group: It includes-

  • Posterior ethmoidal sinuses: Opens in the superior meatus 
  • Sphenoid sinus: Opens in sphenoethmoidal recess

The images below show the location of paranasal sinuses:

questions.text: 500 mg of a drug was administered to a patient. 100 mg was cleared in 60 minutes. How much of the drug would be left in the body after 180  minutes if the excretion of the drug follows zero order kinetics?
questions.solution:
In zero order kinetics, a constant amount of drug is eliminated in unit time. 

In our question, 100 mg of drug is eliminated in 60 minutes (1 hour).

After 180 minutes (3 hours),

  • 3*100 = 300 mg would be eliminated.
  • 500-300 = 200 mg will be the remaining drug in the body.

questions.text: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ________type of joint.
questions.solution:
The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint.

  • The ball part is formed by the rounded head of the talus.
  • The socket is formed by 3 structures: posterior surface of the navicular, anterior articular surface of the calcaneus, and the upper surface of the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring ligament).

questions.text: What is the instrument shown below?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is Barany’s noise box, which masks the non-test ear while testing bone conduction.

Other options:

Option A: Meniett device is a small, portable pulse generator that can control vertigo in patients with Ménière's disease.

Option D: Higginson syringe is used to wash the antrum after an antral puncture is done. This device is shown in the image below.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a primary endpoint in phase 1 studies?
questions.solution:
Efficacy is not a primary endpoint in phase 1 studies. Efficacy can be a secondary endpoint in some studies where patients are recruited.

Safety, tolerability of single/multiple doses and pharmacokinetic parameters are the primary endpoints (Options A, B, and C).

Primary endpoint answers the question -  'what is the purpose of the study for which it is primarily designed', whereas secondary endpoints 'measures the valuable outcome' of the study design.

questions.text: A patient sustained blunt trauma to the eye 6 months ago and now presents with double vision. What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows iridodialysis.

Iridodialysis refers to detachment of the iris root from the ciliary body and is associated with a D-shaped pupil. A black biconvex area is seen at the periphery at the site of detachment.

The given image depicts iridodialysis and a D-shaped pupil.

Other Options:

Option A: Cycloiriditis is inflammation involving both the ciliary body and iris, leading to pain, photophobia, and decreased vision. It's characterized by cells and flare in the anterior chamber, keratic precipitates, and possible synechiae formation.

Option B: Vossius ring is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity, seen on the anterior surface of the lens due to brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens. It is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.

Option D: Coloboma is a congenital anomaly, that develops due to a defect in the closure of the embryonic cleft. It is characterized by poorly developed uveal tissue. These colobomas may involve the optic nerve, choroid, retina, and iris.

questions.text: A 33-year-old lady delivers a baby girl with a rash as shown below and patent ductus arteriosus. What is the type of cataract that is seen with this disease?
questions.solution:
A blueberry muffin rash (image) and patent ductus arteriosus lead to a diagnosis of congenital rubella.  The cataract in congenital rubella syndrome is a pearly white nuclear cataract, which is progressive.

Ocular effects of rubella:

  • Microphthalmia
  • Rubella keratitis
  • Angle-closure glaucoma
  • Nuclear pearly cataract
  • Salt and pepper fundus (most common ocular feature of rubella) due to diffuse chorioretinitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is an early feature of maxillary carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Blood-tinged nasal discharge is an early feature of maxillary carcinoma.

Other early features include:

  • Nasal stuffiness
  • Facial paraesthesias 
  • Pain
  • Epiphora.

These symptoms may be missed or simply treated as sinusitis.

Option B: Lymphatic spread occurs in the late stages of the disease. Among the cervical lymph nodes, submandibular and upper jugular lymph nodes are enlarged.

Option C: Proptosis is a late feature that occurs after the invasion of the orbit. 

Option D: Dental pain is a late feature that occurs due to expansion of the alveolus after the tumor spreads inferiorly.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presented with fever and chills for the last 3 days. A peripheral blood smear revealed the following. Which of the following is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the blood smear showing multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

Falciparum malaria infects both young and mature erythrocytes. Binucleate rings (double chromatin) seen in RBCs are common and they resemble stereo headphones in appearance. The rings are often attached to the margins of the red cells and are described as form applique or accole. There may be several rings present within a single erythrocyte. 

Hypnozoites are not present in P. falciparum infection.

The peripheral smear findings of P. falciparum malaria are:

  • Multiple ring form
  • Accole form
  • Absent schizont
  • Banana shaped gametocytes
  • Maurer's dots

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy rapidly develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination reveals raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. On examination, the liver and kidneys are found to be enlarged. Histopathology of the liver shows deposits of glycogen in an excess amount. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given features are consistent with Von Gierke's disease. It is the most common glycogen storage disease.

The enzyme deficient in this condition is glucose-6-phosphatase (common to both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis). Inheritance is autosomal recessive. 

Glycogen accumulation occurs in the liver and renal tubular cells. Clinical features include:

  • Severe hypoglycemia
  • Ketosis
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperuricemia

A definitive diagnosis is made using a liver biopsy. Fructose and galactose restriction in the diet is advised.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a history of injury to the eye caused by a leaf 5 days ago, resulting in pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. What would be the most likely pathology?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests that it is a fungal corneal ulcer.

Salient features of a fungal corneal ulcer:

  • It is caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter.
  • Signs are more pronounced than symptoms.
  • The corneal ulcer appears dry.
  • Delicate feathery finger-like extensions are present.
  • A sterile, immune ring (yellow line of demarcation) may be present
  • Multiple, small satellite lesions may be present around the ulcer.
  • Usually, a big hypopyon is present.
  • Pigmented ulcer (brownish) may be caused by some dematiaceous species of fungi.
  • Perforation in mycotic ulcer is rare but can occur.
  • The most common cause is Aspergillus.

Image: Fungal corneal ulcer, with the arrowhead indicating a satellite lesion

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

questions.text: A man has been arrested and booked under Sec. 304-B of the Indian penal code. Which of the following offenses has he been accused of?
questions.solution:
He has been accused of and arrested for dowry death. Section 304-B of the Indian Penal Code (I.P.C) deals with dowry deaths.

This legal provision comes into effect when the untimely demise of a woman occurs by burns/bodily injury or any other cause apart from normal circumstances within the first 7 years of her marriage. Evidence of cruelty or harassment by her spouse or relatives of her spouse in connection with demands for dowry must be shown. An individual accused of dowry death (cognizable, non-bailable) is liable to imprisonment from 7 years to life. 

Other options:

Option A: Death by rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide is punishable (imprisonment for up to 2 years with/without fine) by Sec. 304-A IPC. 

Option C: Culpable homicide is punishable by Sec. 299 IPC. It is an offense wherein the accused intentionally causes death or bodily injury likely to cause death.

Option D: Grievous hurt is punishable by Sec. 320 IPC. Grievous hurt refers to any hurt that endangers life, or which causes the victim to be in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits for a period of twenty days. This includes emasculation, permanent privation of the sight of either eye, permanent privation of the hearing of either ear, the privation of any member or joint or the destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfiguration of the head or face, and fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.

questions.text: A physiologist studies about the sensor which detects elevated sodium and decreases the glomerular filtration rate. In the given image of the juxtaglomerular apparatus, which of the following structures acts as this sensor?
questions.solution:
The structure marked '1' is the macula densa cells in the distal convoluted tubule and they are involved in detecting elevated sodium levels and thereby decreasing the glomerular filtration rate

The given image constitutes the juxtaglomerular apparatus and has the following parts:

  • Macula densa: Specialized cells at the start of Distal Convoluted Tubule form the macula densa. They detect sodium and chloride concentrations of the fluid in the tubule (Chemoreceptor). In response to elevated sodium and chloride, the macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing the flow of blood to the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate. This happens as follows: When there is increased sodium, there is increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity which leads to increased ATP hydrolysis causing more adenosine formation. The adenosine receptors on the macula densa cells stimulate it to release more calcium, so that there is vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, thereby decreasing the GFR.
  • Granular cells/JG cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, they secrete renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in turn, increases blood pressure. They are denoted by '2' in the given image.
  • Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole. They are marked as '3' in the given image.
    The structure marked as '4' in the given image is the proximal tubular cell. It is involved in the process of glomerulotubular balance. 

When an increase in the GFR occurs, there is a consequential increase in the reabsorption of the solutes and water in the proximal convoluted tubule. This process is called the glomerulotubular balance and it keeps the percentage of the reabsorbed solutes at constant levels.

questions.text: A 25-year old man presents with chronic anemia and gall stones. His father and paternal aunt had a similar illness that was treated successfully by splenectomy. His peripheral blood smear showed spherocytes as given in the image. What is the mode of the inheritance of the given clinical condition?
questions.solution:
The above image showing spherocytes in the peripheral blood smear and, along with the history, strongly suggest a diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis. Inheritance of hereditary spherocytosis is mainly autosomal dominant.

It is a structural RBC disorder making the RBCs more spheroid, less deformable, and more vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction. This decreases the lifespan of RBCs.

questions.text: A drug dealer was arrested and strips of dried blotting paper printed with colorful graphics were confiscated from him. Which of the following substances is commonly sold like that?
questions.solution:
Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) is most commonly sold as small squares of dried blotter paper printed with colorful graphics.

It is a colorless, tasteless, odorless, water-soluble substance. A heavy user of LSD is called an acid head.

questions.text: Decrease in pH shifts the oxygen dissociation curve to_____

choices.text: On either side depending on other factors

questions.solution:
The pH decreasing from the normal value shifts the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve, to the right.

Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve (OHDC)

  • This is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the % saturation of Hb with O2.
  • It is normally sigmoid-shaped.
  • If OHDC is shifted to the right, it means that the affinity of Hb for O2 has become less (which favors O2 delivery) i.e. higher the P50 - Right shift Releases oxygen

Shift to the right is caused by: (Conditions with an increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat 
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis
  • Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG
  • Sickle cell anemia - reduced affinity for O2

Conditions that cause a left shift in the oxygen hemoglobin curve are:

  • Increased oxygen
  • Decreased carbon dioxide
  • Increased pH
  • Decreased temperature
  • Decreased 2,3-Biphosphoglycerate.
  • Fetal hemoglobin

questions.text: Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome is caused by
questions.solution:
Waterhouse-Friderichsen Syndrome also known as hemorrhagic adrenalitis or fulminant meningococcemia is a complication seen in infection with meningococci, characterized by bilateral adrenal gland hemorrhage.

Complications : 

  • Shock, extensive haemorrhage within the skin and fall into coma.
  • Death usually after a few hours, adrenal insufficiency being the immediate cause.

TREATMENT

  • Fulminant meningococcemia is a medical emergency and needs to be treated with adequate antibiotics as fast as possible.
  • Ceftriaxone is an antibiotic commonly employed today.

    • Tonsil of cerebellum.

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the hospital following a snake bite. The attendants have also brought the snake with them for identification. The image of the snake is given below. The poison of the snake is mainly:
questions.solution:
The image shows a banded krait. The poison of this snake is mainly neurotoxic.

The banded krait can be identified by the alternating black and yellow cross-bands along its back and the presence of hexagonal scales. Its tail has a blunt ending with a swelling at the tip. In addition, a black mark can be found on its neck that extends to the eyes.

The initial presentation includes vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, blurred vision, perioral paresthesia, hyperacusis, dizziness, vertigo, and piloerection ('gooseflesh').

Ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia is the first sign of paralysis to set in followed by involvement of the face, tongue, neck muscles, and muscles of deglutition. 

Ultimately, respiratory failure is precipitated either by airway obstruction or paralysis of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles.

The neurotoxic symptoms of the banded krait bite are reversible with the use of antivenoms or anticholinesterase drugs. In some cases the symptoms may even subside spontaneously after a week.

questions.text: What is the refractive power of a lens whose focal length is 0.75 m?
questions.solution:
If the focal length of the lens is 0.75m, then the refractive power would be 1.33D.

Based on the given formula, Refractive power (dioptre) =  1/focal length in metres.

So, for the given question, refractive power (D) = 1/0.75 = 1.33 D.

questions.text: A young male patient presented with complaints of bluish-black discoloration of the sclera and pinna for the last 6 months. Also, the patient's urine turns black on standing as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The blackening of urine on standing is characteristic of alkaptonuria and results due to the excretion of homogentisic acid in the urine.

It is an autosomal recessive condition due to a deficiency of homogentisate oxidase (also called homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase).

The homogentisic acid is then oxidized to benzoquinone acetate and polymerized to form black-colored alkapton bodies, which deposit in soft tissues like cartilage and is called ochronosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with an abdominal mass. After laparotomy, the mass is removed, which on microscopic examination, demonstrates a cystic cavity filled with hair and keratin debris. The wall contains skin, adnexal tissue, thyroid tissue, and neural tissue. All of the tissues are similar to those normally found, and no malignant changes are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is consistent with mature teratoma.

Mature teratoma:

  • Cystic teratomas are usually found in young women during the active reproductive years. 
  • They are bilateral in 10% to 15% of cases.
  • They are unilocular cysts containing hair and sebaceous material sometimes cartilage, bone, thyroid, and neural tissue.
  • Microscopically, the cyst wall is composed of stratified squamous epithelium, with underlying sebaceous glands, hair shafts, and other skin adnexal structures.
  • About 1% of the dermoids undergo malignant transformation, most commonly to squamous cell carcinoma, but also to other cancers as well (e.g., thyroid carcinoma, melanoma).

 

Image: Mature cystic teratoma

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

questions.text: A young female patient presents to your clinic with nasal obstruction. Physical examination revealed a wide, roomy nasal cavity, a pale nasal mucosa, and greyish-black dry crusts that improved after modified Young's procedure. Identify the clinical feature likely to be associated with this condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of atrophic rhinitis, and merciful anosmia is associated with this condition. Merciful anosmia is when the patient has marked anosmia and is unable to smell the foul odor coming from their nose.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammation of the nose characterized by atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. It is more common in females and starts around puberty. The patient presents with nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers. It is associated with foul odor from their nose but the patient is unable to smell it because of merciful anosmia. Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements. On examination nasal mucosa appears pale, greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. 

Medical management is done using warm saline for nasal irrigation, removal of crusts and administering local antibiotics like kemicetine antiozaena solution(containing chloromycetin, oestradiol, and vitamin D2).

Surgical management involves:

  • In Young's operation, both the nostrils are closed completely by raising flaps within the nasal vestibule. They are opened after 6 months and during this time, the mucosa comes back to normal and the crusting is reduced.
  • Modified young operation is a modified version of Young's operation where the nostrils are only partially closed. The results are the same compared to Young's operation and it is done to avoid discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils. 

Other options:

Option A: Offensive cheesy discharge is seen in an uncommon condition called rhinitis caseosa. It is usually unilateral and affects males. The disease arises from chronic sinusitis with the collection of inspissated cheesy material.

Option C: Paroxysmal sneezing refers to bouts of sneezing in the morning and is associated with allergic rhinitis and vasomotor rhinitis. 

Option D: Allergic salute is the constant upward rubbing motion of the nose simulating a salute, leading to transverse nasal crease across the dorsum of the nose. Seen in allergic rhinitis. 

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

  • More common in females 
  • Usually starts at puberty
  • It is a bilateral condition
  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia)
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale

questions.text: An old woman presented to the OPD with dysuria and frequent micturition. Urinalysis showed pus cells, and culture on MacConkey agar showed the following. Which organism is involved here?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and growth of lactose-fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar suggest a diagnosis of urinary tract infection by Escherichia coli. 

Enterobacteriaceae family is classified based on their action on lactose present in MacConkey's medium:

  • Lactose fermenters - Escherichia, Klebsiella
  • Late lactose fermenters - Shigella sonnei
  • Non-lactose fermenters- Salmonella species, Shigella species

The image below shows lactose fermenting and non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar. 

Mnemonic to remember non-lactose fermenters: (SPY PSM)

  • Salmonella
  • Proteus
  • Yersinia
  • Providencia- late fermenter
  • Shigella (except S.sonnei which is a late lactose fermenter)
  • Morganella

questions.text: The following procedure was planned for a patient with a suspicion of Guillain-Barré syndrome. What is not pierced during this procedure?
questions.solution:
A lumbar puncture is planned for this patient with a suspicion of Guillain-Barré syndrome. The posterior longitudinal ligament is not pierced during lumbar puncture.

Structures pierced during lumbar puncture (in that order):

  • Subcutaneous tissue

  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Epidural space
  • Dura mater

choices.text: Mental Health for all. Greater Investment – Greater Access.

questions.text: A 48-year-old construction worker presented with complaints of unilateral loss of sweating on the face. He had a history of trauma to his back 1 month ago. Examination revealed the following findings. What is the likely site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Horner's or Bernard-Horner's syndrome. It can be caused by the lesion of the white ramus of T1. 

Horner's syndrome is characterized by a constricted pupil (miosis), drooping of the upper eyelid (ptosis), and an absence of sweating of the face (anhidrosis). It occurs due to the disruption of the sympathetic nerve supply.

In the autonomic nervous system, the sympathetic plexus is thoracolumbar and the parasympathetic plexus is craniosacral.

The sympathetic plexus is formed along the side of the spinal cord by white ramus inflow (preganglionic nerve fibers) and gray ramus outflow (postganglionic) and it extends from T1-L2. 

In Horner's syndrome, since the sympathetic inflow is disrupted, the white ramus of the spinal cord is affected as shown below.

The difference between the sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglions are tabulated below.

  Sympathetic ganglions Parasympathetic ganglions
Location Closer to the spinal cord Closer to the organ
Pre-ganglionic fibers Short  Long
Post-ganglionic fibers Long Short

Related Pearl: Horner's syndrome

Horner's Syndrome:

Horner's syndrome occurring due to occulo-sympathetic paresis is characterized by the classic triad of:

  • Mild ptosis (due to paralysis of Muller's muscle).
  • Miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae).
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating (anhydrosis).

Other features include:

  • Mild enophthalmos,
  • Loss of cilio-spinal reflex,
  • Heterochromia, i.e., the ipsilateral iris is lighter in colour,
  • Pupil is slow to dilate, and there occurs slight elevation of lower eyelid.

Cocaine test (2% to 4%): Small pupils fail to dilate in Horner's syndrome.

In congenital Horner's syndrome, the additional features seen are heterochromia iridis and unilateral straight hair.

questions.text: On examining the oral cavity of a patient who presented with fever and a sore throat, you notice a greyish-white membrane over the tonsils. Which of the following conditions would you not consider as a differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ludwig’s angina is not associated with the formation of a grey-white membrane.

Ludwig's angina is characterized by rapidly spreading infection of the sublingual space initially and later the submaxillary space, often dentogenic in origin.

Patients present with symptoms such as fever, chills, malaise, and dysphagia. Some patients may have a hot potato voice or they might not be able to speak at all.

D/D for membrane over tonsil:

  • Streptococcus & other pyogenic organisms
  • Diphtheria
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Vincent’s angina
  • Leukemia
  • Candida
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Malignancy
  • Aphthous ulcer
  • Traumatic ulcer

Other Options: 

Option A: The image given below shows acute streptococcus tonsillitis presenting with a membrane over the tonsil.

Option B: The image given below shows pseudomembrane over tonsil typically seen in diphtheria.

Option D: The image given below shows oral candidiasis.

questions.text: In the given image, the artery of epistaxis is indicated by _____.
questions.solution:
Structure marked C is the sphenopalatine artery which is called the “artery of epistaxis”.

It is called the artery of epistaxis since the majority of the blood supply to the nasal cavity is by the sphenopalatine artery and it is the most commonly involved artery in epistaxis.

Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows:

  • A: Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • B: Posterior ethmoidal artery
  • D: Greater palatine artery

questions.text: Crippling fluorosis occurs at what levels of fluoride intake:
questions.solution:
Crippling fluorosis is seen at fluoride intake >10mg/L, which in this question is 11mg/L.

Fluorosis seen with corresponding levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: 1.5mg/L
  • Skeletal fluorosis: 3-6mg/L
  • Crippling fluorosis: >10mg/L
  • Genu valgum: In people consuming jowar(sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.
  • Nalgonda technique is used for defluoridation which involves addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation and filtration.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man experienced chest pain 4 days ago. He now has increasing dyspnea and an irregular pulse. The representative gross appearance of his interventricular myocardium is shown here. Which of the following microscopic changes is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
The above image shows myocardial infarction, which is characterized by coagulative necrosis.

In coagulative necrosis, the cells are dead but the outline and architecture of the cells are preserved.

This is because the cell injury is mainly due to the denaturation of proteins.

Examples of coagulative necrosis:

  • Ischemic injury in all organs, except the brain
  • Dry gangrene

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with sudden onset blindness. He gives a history of frequent headaches along the sides of his scalp. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of giant cell arteritis.

Giant cell/temporal arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder of large to small-sized arteries that especially affects the temporal arteries. It is seen in people over 50 years of age. It usually presents with facial pain or headache along the course of the superficial temporal artery.

It can also affect:

  • The ophthalmic arteries- leading to sudden onset diplopia or blindness
  • The aorta- leading to giant-cell aortitis
  • The vertebral arteries

A biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Note: Giant cell arteritis needs to be promptly diagnosed and treated with steroids to prevent permanent blindness.

questions.text: A neonate presents with feeding difficulty and failure to thrive. Her urine has a peculiar burnt sugar odor due to an excess of branched-chain amino acids. Which of the following is unlikely to be elevated?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD). Lysine is not a branched-chain amino acid and hence is unlikely to be elevated.

Branched-chain amino acids are:

  • Valine (V)
  • Isoleucine (I)
  • Leucine (L)

MSUD is due to the deficiency of branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase complex (BCKDC), leading to the formation of branched-chain amino acids and their toxic by-products (ketoacids) in the blood and urine. There is a peculiar odor of burnt sugar found in urine, sweat, and cerumen.

Related Pearl: Maple syrup urine disease(MSUD)

questions.text: In a patient suffering from parkinsons's disease, what is the most likely reason behind the gradual decline in the therapeutic effect of L-dopa?

choices.text: Inhibitory pathways grow into the basal ganglia from the frontal lobe.
There is an increase in circulating α-synuclein.
The dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra continue to degenerate.

questions.solution:
The most likely reason behind the gradual decline in the therapeutic effect of L-dopa in a patient suffering from Parkinson's disease is the continued degeneration of the dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. Since endogenous production of dopamine continues to decline, the exogenous source of dopamine (i.e. L-dopa) alone fails to maintain the same level of therapeutic effect.

Parkinson's disease (Paralysis Agitans) was shown to result from the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta. The fibers to the putamen (part of the striatum) are most severely affected.

Dopaminergic neurons and dopamine receptors are steadily lost with age in the basal ganglia in healthy individuals, and an acceleration of these losses apparently precipitates parkinsonism. Symptoms appear when 60–80% of the nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons degenerate.

questions.text: What is the percentage of cytosine in DNA if the percentage of thymine residues 28%.
questions.solution:
The percentage of cytosine in DNA will be 22%.

According to Chargaff's rule in cellular DNA regardless of species:

Purines = Pyrimidines.

Sum of Purine =Sum of Pyrimidines i.e A+G=C+T.

In the question it is given that thymine is 28%, therefore adenine is also 28%. Hence adenine+thymine = 56% and Guanine + cytosine = 44%. 

No of Guanine=No of Cytosine, so the percentage of cytosine = 44/2 = 22%.

questions.text: A patient on HAART presents with complaints of fever and expectorant cough for two weeks. What is the investigation to be ordered first?
questions.solution:
An HIV patient suspected to have TB is directly investigated by CB-NAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test).

TB is a very serious infection in the immunocompromised and can lead to its most severe form as miliary TB and cause death. Since TB in HIV does not have its typical presentation, early suspicion and advanced diagnosis is the key to preventing mortality.

    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges
    • Fourth part of vertebral artery surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    • Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    • Tonsil of cerebellum.

questions.text: The glycosaminoglycan that plays an important role in cellular migration is _________
questions.solution:
Hyaluronic acid plays an important role in cellular migration.

  • Composed of repeating disaccharide units of N-acetyl glucosamine and glucuronic acid.
  • Serves as a lubricant and shock absorber especially in joints.
  • Plays an important role in permitting cell migration during morphogenesis, wound repair, and tumor cell metastasis.
  • Location: Synovial fluid, vitreous humor, the umbilical cord, cartilage.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered to be the most unsanitary method of waste disposal?
questions.solution:
The most unsanitary method of waste disposal is dumping.

Methods of waste disposal include:

  • Controlled tipping or sanitary landfill - The most satisfactory method of refuse disposal when suitable land is available.
  • Incineration - Method of choice when suitable land is not available.
  • Composting
  • Manure pits
  • Burial
  • Dumping

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criterion for identifying ‘at-risk’ infants in a child health clinic?
questions.solution:
Birth weight less than 2.5kg (and not 2.8kg) is a criterion for identifying at-risk infants. At a child health clinic, the criteria to identify at-risk infants include:

  • Birth weight less than 2.5 kgs
  • Twins 
  • Birth order of 5 or more
  • Artificial feeding
  • Weight below 70% of the expected weight
  • Failure to gain weight during 3 successive months
  • Children with PEM, diarrhea
  • Working mother or single parent

questions.text: Which among the following is not a sexual spore?
questions.solution:
Sporangiospore is not a sexual spore. It is an asexual spore.

Fungi can be classified into 4 classes based on sexual spore formation:

Class Sexual spore Asexual spore
Glomerulomycetes Oospores, Zygospores Sporangiospores
Ascomycetes Ascospores Conidia
Basidiomycetes Basidiospores Conidia
Fungi imperfecti (Deuteromycetes) Yet to be identified Conidia

Fungi imperfecti (Deuteromycetes): These are the fungi whose sexual phases are yet to be identified. Most of the fungi of medical importance belong to this group.

Note: The earlier classification of Phycomycetes, under which Zygomycetes, Oomycetes, and other sub-phyla were present, is now obsolete. Phylum Glomerulomycota has replaced it.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on spore formation

It is classified into 4 types:

Glomeromycota:

  • Lower fungi with non-septate hyphae.
  • Asexual spores are called sporangiospores – within swollen sac-like structure called sporangia
  • Sexual spores are called zygospores and oospores

 

Ascomycota: 

  • Asexual spores are called conidia.
  • Sexual spores are called ascospores - formed within a sac or ascus.

 

Basidiomycota:

  • Asexual spores are called conidia.
  • Sexual spores are called basidiospores (on a basidium or base).

 

Deuteromycetes: (fungi imperfecti or hypomycetes) – sexual stages yet to be discovered.

questions.text: An elderly patient admitted to the ICU with multiple comorbidities developed exposure keratitis and ulceration. An ophthalmology opinion was sought. On fundoscopy, the resident found the following picture. What is this most likely due to?
questions.solution:
The given image suggests a diagnosis of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The hallmark of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is neovascularization. Abnormal new vessel formation, which occurs on the inner (vitreous) surface of the retina and may extend into the vitreous cavity, can cause vitreous hemorrhage. Neovascularization is often accompanied by pre-retinal fibrous tissue, which, along with the vitreous, can contract, resulting in traction retinal detachment. In addition, tiny microaneurysms can also be seen.The treatment available for proliferative diabetic retinopathy is photocoagulation of the ischaemic areas to reduce the metabolic demand and decrease or prevent the release of vasoproliferative factors.

Stages and fundus picture in diabetic retinopathy:

Background Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • Microaneurysms 
  • Dot and Blot hemorrhages 
  • Exudates

Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (indicates progressive retinal ischemia):

  • Intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities
  • Venous changes (such as beading)
  • Cotton wool spots
  • Deep retinal hemorrhages

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • NeoVascularization of the optic Disc (NVD)
  • NeoVascularization Elsewhere in the periphery of the fundus (NVE)

Advanced Diabetic Eye Disease:

  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: A young male patient undergoes a submucosal resection. One week later, he presents with bilateral nasal obstruction and pressure sensation over the nasal bridge. On examination, smooth, rounded swelling of the septum is seen bilaterally. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is a septal hematoma. 

Septal hematoma occurs when there is an accumulation of blood beneath the periosteum or perichondrium of the nasal septum. The most common cause of hematoma is nasal surgery or trauma. However, it is also seen in individuals with bleeding disorders. 

Patients present with bilateral nasal obstruction, frontal headache, and pressure sensation over the bridge. 

Examination, as seen in this patient, will show bilateral smooth rounded swellings of the nasal septum. If palpated, the mass will be soft and fluctuant.

The following image shows the bilateral, smooth, rounded swellings of the nasal septum indicative of septal hematoma. 

Treatment of septal hematomas involves aspiration with a wide bore needle if small, and incision and drainage if large. The incision can be made parallel to the nasal floor. Removing a small piece of nasal mucosa will aid in drainage. After drainage, the nose has to be packed bilaterally to avoid reaccumulation. 

Other options: 

Option A - Septal abscess occurs usually when there is a secondary infection of a septal hematoma. It is characterized by fever, chills, and frontal headaches. 

Option C - Septal perforation can occur after nasal surgery. Features depend on the size of the perforation. Smaller perforations can present with whistling while the larger perforations will present with epistaxis and crust formation. An image of septal perforation is given below.

Option D - Septal deviation is characterized by chronic unilateral or bilateral nasal obstruction. There is usually an external deformity and associated sinusitis, epistaxis, and anosmia.

Related Pearl: Septal Haematoma

  • Septal hematoma is a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum
  • Causes: Trauma, septal surgery and bleeding disorders
  • Clinical features: Bilateral nasal obstruction (most common presenting feature), frontal headache
  • Treatment:
    • Aspiration of small hematomas
    • Incision and drainage of large hematomas followed by nasal packing
    • Systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation
  • Complications: Septal abscess, depression of dorsum, permanently thickened septum

Related Pearl: Nasal Septum

Septum proper is an osseocartilaginous framework made up of:

  • Septal or quadrilateral cartilage
  • Perpendicular plate of ethmoid
  • Vomer
  • Others – crest of nasal bones, nasal spine of frontal bone, rostrum of sphenoid, crest of palatine bones and the crest maxilla, and the anterior nasal spine of maxilla

questions.text: A tall man presents with complaints of infertility. Examination shows gynecomastia and reduced secondary sexual characteristics. Karyotyping analysis revealed an XXY karyotype. Which of the following statements is not true about the condition?

choices.text: Levels of follicle-stimulating hormone are reduced.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Klinefelter's syndrome. In Klinefelter's syndrome, the follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) levels are elevated. 

Clinical features:

  1. Eunuchoid body habitus with abnormally long legs;
  2. Atrophic testes
  3. Lack of secondary male characteristics such as the deep voice, beard, and male distribution of pubic hair.
  4. Gynecomastia may be present. The mean IQ is somewhat lower than normal, but mental retardation is uncommon.

Patients with Klinefelter syndrome have a higher risk for breast cancer (20 times more common than in normal males), extragonadal germ-cell tumors, and autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: A patient with a long-standing history of thyroglossal cyst develops a neck swelling. The biopsy of the lesion is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows psammoma bodies, which are seen in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. This type of carcinoma is associated with a history of long-standing unresected thyroglossal cyst.

Psammoma bodies are concentrically calcified structures often present within the cores of papillae in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. These structures are almost never found in follicular and medullary carcinomas. They arise from:

  • Infarction and dystrophic calcification of papillae tips
  • Calcification of intra-lymphatic tumor thrombi.

Psammoma bodies are seen in:

  • Papillary carcinoma (thyroid, kidney, endometrium, lungs)
  • Prolactinoma
  • Meningioma
  • Papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary

questions.text: Slow waves of peristalsis are generated by:
questions.solution:
The interstitial cells of Cajal undergo cyclic changes in membrane potential due to unique ion channels that peri­odically open and produce inward (pacemaker) currents that generate slow-wave activity.

Interstitial cells of Cajal are the pacemaker cells of the GIT that initiate the basic electrical rhythm (BER). These are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features.

In the stomach and the small intestine, these cells are located in the circular smooth muscle layer near the myenteric plexus. In the colon, they are at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer.

The slow waves usually do not by themselves cause muscle contraction in most parts of the gastrointestinal tract, except perhaps in the stomach. Instead, they mainly excite the appearance of intermittent spike potentials, and the spike potentials in turn actually excite the muscle contraction.

Note: Gastrointestinal stromal tumors arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 2-week old infant to you with complaints of noisy breathing that worsens during feeding. On direct laryngoscopy, the following is seen. What is the preferred treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and omega-shaped epiglottis are suggestive of laryngomalacia. Conservative treatment is preferred for laryngomalacia as this condition self-corrects by two years of age.

Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty is required in severe laryngomalacia. Signs of  severe laryngomalacia include:

  • Difficulty feeding
  • Increased effort in breathing
  • Poor weight gain 
  • Pauses in the breathing 
  • Frequent spitting up

questions.text: During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the surgeon is making an attempt to identify the Calot’s triangle. All of the following identified by the surgeon are the boundaries of the Calot's triangle, except ____.
questions.solution:
The inferior surface of the liver marked as 4 does not form the boundary of Calot’s triangle. It forms the superior boundary of the hepatobiliary triangle.

The boundaries of Calot’s triangle are: 3C's

  • Medially – Common hepatic duct
  • Inferiorly – Cystic duct
  • Superior – Cystic artery

Clinical importance: Identification of Calot’s triangle is important during laparoscopic cholecystectomy for safe ligation and division of cystic duct and cystic artery.

questions.text: A 23-year-old lady presents with the lesions shown below. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The lesions shown are cold sores, also known as herpes labialis caused by Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1). Herpes labialis primarily affects the lip and typically present as thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down with superficial ulcers. They generally heal without scarring.

HSV-1 can be isolated from lesions in and around the mouth and is transmitted by direct contact or droplet spread from cases or carriers. HSV-2 is responsible for the majority of genital herpes infections and is commonly transmitted venereally.

The images below show lesions of herpes labialis.

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the histological image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows histological section of ureter.

The image shows a thick, fibroelastic, lamina propria lying underneath the stratified, transitional epithelium. There are no mucosal or submucosal glands and no submucosa. There is a layer of smooth muscle outside the mucosa. The outer adventitial layer has fibroelastic connective tissue, with blood vessels, lymphatics and nerves.

questions.solution: Coma occurs when glucose levels fall below 30 mg/dL.

questions.text: A young woman comes to the Suraksha clinic of the local primary health centre. She is examined and the yellow kit is prescribed to her as treatment. Which of the following symptoms is most likely seen in the patient?
questions.solution:
Lower abdominal pain is the most likely symptom seen in the patient. 

The National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) has started the Suraksha clinic to deal with sexually transmitted infections (STI) and reproductive tract infections (RTI). Pre-packed STI/RTI color-coded kits are supplied through STI/RTI clinics free of cost. The kits are obtained centrally and then supplied to all state AIDS control societies. 

Kit Syndrome/s

Kit 1
(Grey)

Urethral discharge

Cervical discharge

Ano-rectal discharge

Painful scrotal swelling
Kit 2 (Green) Vaginal discharge / Vaginitis
Kit 3 (White) Non-herpetic genital ulcers

Kit 4
(Blue)

Non-herpetic genital ulcers if allergic to penicillin

Kit 5
(Red)

 Herpetic genital ulcers
Kit 6 (Yellow) Lower abdominal pain

Kit 7
(Black)

 Inguinal bubo

Other symptoms seen in the patients prescribed with the yellow kit are: 

  • Fever
  • Vaginal Discharge
  • Menstrual irregularities (heavy, irregular vaginal bleeding)
  • Dysmenorrhoea, dyspareunia, dysuria and tenesmus
  • Lower backache
  • Cervical motion tenderness

The kit contains cefixime 400 mg tablet to have immediately, metronidazole 400 mg tablet, and doxycycline 100 mg tablet to have twice a day for 14 days. Along with this, the male partner should be treated with kit 1. 

Lower abdominal pain should be followed up on the 3rd, 7rd, and 14th day and a referral should be made if symptoms persist. 

Related Pearl: Partner management in sexually transmitted infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: An 18-month-child with gonadal dysgenesis presents with a large abdominal mass. On resection, the gross appearance of the mass is as seen below. Which of the following tumors does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor).

The history of a large abdominal mass in a young child and the resected gross specimen, which shows well-circumscribed tumor with multiple necrotic, hemorrhagic, and cystic changes seen in the upper pole of the kidney, is strongly suggestive of Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma). The history of gonadal dysgenesis aids the diagnosis of Wilms tumor, which is associated with Denys–Drash syndrome.

Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma): It is the most common primary renal tumor of childhood (peaks 2-5 years of age).

Other options

  • Renal cell carcinoma is a malignant tumor of adults.
  • Angiomyolipoma may rarely be seen in children.
  • Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor of childhood arising from adrenal medulla; however, it is not associated with gonadal dysgenesis. 

Image: The histopathological image shows the characteristic triphasic components:

  1. Malignant small round (blue) cells (blastemal component).
  2. Tubular structures/rosettes (epithelial component).
  3. Loose pauci-cellular stroma with spindle cells (stromal component)

Related Pearl: Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text: The cells that will test negative for all mitochondrial markers are______
questions.solution:
The cells that will test negative for all mitochondrial markers are mature red blood cells, as they do not have mitochondria.

Lack of mitochondria is the reason why red blood cells exclusively use anaerobic glycolysis to generate ATP.

questions.text: In which of the following phases of the bacterial growth curve does sporulation occur?
questions.solution:
Sporulation occurs in the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve, which is marked as C in the image.

Phases of bacterial growth: 

  • Lag phase (Marked as A): Occurs immediately after the seeding of a culture media. Cell size increases and maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase. This initial period is the time required for adaptation to a new environment, during which the necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication to proceed.
  • Log phase or exponential phase (Marked as B): In this phase, cells start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially or by geometric progression with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. 
  • Stationary phase (Marked as C): Cell division stops due to depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. It's a state of equilibrium, where the number of new cells forms equals the number of cells that die. Sporulation occurs during this phase. 
  • Phase of decline (Marked as D): In this phase, the population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation, and action of autolytic enzymes. Involution forms are common.

questions.text: All the following are notifiable occupational diseases under the Factories act except ____________.
questions.solution: Bagassosis is not a notifiable disease.

questions.text: The most common cause of bilateral proptosis in children is ______.
questions.solution:
The most common cause of bilateral proptosis in children is neuroblastoma.

Most common cause:

Unilateral proptosis Bilateral proptosis
In children: Orbital cellulitis In children: Neuroblastoma and leukemia (chloroma)
In adults: Thyroid ophthalmopathy In adults: Thyroid ophthalmopathy

 

Image: Bilateral proptosis

questions.text: Identify the following instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is a myringotome. It is a sharp surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum during myringotomy. 

Other options-

Option A- Lempert’s curette (scoop) is used for the removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery.

 

Option C- MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker used in mastoid surgery to explore the air cells with one end and to curette the intervening septa and granulations with the other.

Option D- Tilley Lichtwitz trocar and cannula are used for proof punctures (antral lavage). Puncture using the trocar is done in the inferior meatus because this site is easily accessible and safe.

questions.text: Malate shuttle is important in _______.
questions.solution:
Malate shuttle is important in both, gluconeogenesis and glycolysis.

Malate shuttle is a biochemical system for translocating impermeable electrons (NADH) or substrates (oxaloacetate), in the form of a permeable substance, malate. The semipermeable inner mitochondrial membrane is permeable to malate.

In glycolysis, the impermeable NADH produced in the cytosol (of liver and cardiac cells) are taken up into mitochondria for oxidation via malate shuttle.

In gluconeogenesis, pyruvate in the mitochondria yields impermeable oxaloacetate, which is converted to aspartate and translocated to the cytosol via malate shuttle for the synthesis of glucose.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with multiple tense itchy blisters on the trunk and thigh region. Histopathology demonstrates subepidermal, non-acantholytic blisters. Direct immunofluorescence shows IgG deposition in a linear pattern.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is highly suggestive of bullous pemphigoid.

Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by tense itchy bulla in the flexor areas and trunk which do not rupture easily. In bullous pemphigoid, the antibodies are formed against bullous pemphigoid antigens (BPAGs)- BP 180 and BP 230, which are components of hemidesmosomes. 

The separation of bullous pemphigoid from pemphigus is based on the identification of subepidermal, nonacantholytic blisters. Immunofluorescence shows IgG and C3 deposits in a continuous linear pattern at the dermo-epidermal junction. 

Image: Direct immunofluorescence—continuous linear pattern at the dermo-epidermal junction

questions.text: A person with radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy develops nephrotic-range proteinuria. Which of the following would be the most likely histological finding in the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features in a patient with radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy and nephrotic-range proteinuria are suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to a secondary cause. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) would be the most likely histological pattern in such patients.

FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with characteristic degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells as well as effacement of foot processes.

Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis is due to entrapment of plasma proteins and increased extracellular matrix deposition.

Classification of FSGS:

Primary

Secondary

Inherited

Idiopathic FSGS

HIV associated

Mutations in genes that encode proteins localized to the slit diaphragm

Ex: Podocin, Alpha- actin 4, TRPC6
 

Heroin addiction

  
 

Sickle cell disease

  
 

Obesity

  
 

Focal glomerulonephritis (e.g., IgA nephropathy)

  
 

Renal ablation, unilateral renal agenesis or renal dysplasia, reflux nephropathy

  
 

Hypertensive nephropathy

  

Light microscopy: Focal segmental sclerosis and hyalinization of the glomeruli; Lipid droplets

Electron microscopy: Diffuse effacement of the podocyte foot processes as well as focal detachment and degeneration of the epithelial cells; no electron-dense deposits.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presented with abdominal distention and increased irritability for 10 days. Physical examination showed jaundice, hepatomegaly and a boiled cabbage odour. Investigations were notable for elevated transaminases and succinylacetone. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of type 1 tyrosinemia (tyrosinosis). It is treated by a combination of nitisinone and dietary restriction of phenylalanine and tyrosine.

Type 1 tyrosinemia is the most common form of tyrosinemia caused by defective fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme. They usually present between 2-6 months of age with acute liver failure. They may also present with peripheral neuropathy resembling acute porphyria. Renal involvement is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, hypophosphatemia and vitamin D resistant rickets.

An odour resembling boiled cabbage resulting from increased methionine metabolites can be noted. Elevated levels of succinylacetone in blood or urine is diagnostic of type 1 tyrosinemia.

Note: A boiled cabbage odour can also occur in hypermethioninemia.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fatigue for the past three months. Her peripheral blood smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia. The stool microscopy reveals the following. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of iron deficiency anemia and the stool microscopy showing the egg is suggestive of infection by Ancylostoma duodenale.

The hookworm eggs are oval or elliptical in shape, colorless, and non-bile stained. It has a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane. The ovum is segmented with 4 to 8 blastomeres when passed in feces. There is a clear space between the segmented ovum and eggshell. 

Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin or subcutaneous tissue.

A. duodenale or N. americanus ingest blood, secrete anticoagulants, and interfere with the absorption of iron, B12, and folic acid. This leads to iron deficiency anemia and protein-energy malnutrition resulting from blood loss.

The average blood loss of the host per worm per day is 0.2 mL with Ancylostoma duodenale and 0.03 mL with Necator americanus.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A normal anion gap metabolic acidosis occurs in patients with_____
questions.solution:
Diarrhoea is a cause of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis produced as a result of increased HCO3- loss in feces.

This is because a decrease in HCO3- is replaced by an increase in the concentration of Cl-.  This is a measurable anion and hence the anion gap is normal.

Extra - edge : Siggard-Anderson curve normogram is used to plot the acid-base composition of the blood

questions.text: A patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, a blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate was seen. What is the most important risk factor for this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucormycosis and the most important risk factor among these is diabetes.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic mycosis. It is typically seen in patients with diabetes mellitus and immunocompromised patients. Mucormycosis recently emerged as an important superinfection in COVID-19 patients, especially in India. The surge in cases is most likely due to diabetes mellitus and steroid use.

Risk factors for the infection include the following:

  • Uncontrolled diabetes
  • Acidosis (especially diabetic ketoacidosis)
  • Steroid treatment
  • Lymphomas and leukemias
  • Immunodeficiencies
  • Severe burns 

The rhino-orbital-cerebral is the most common form of mucormycosis. Patients present with rhinitis, eye or facial pain, and facial numbness followed by the onset of conjunctival suffusion and swelling along with blurry vision. 

Patients can have local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge typically resembling the presentation of invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discoloration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

Diagnosis is made by biopsy with histopathologic examination. The biopsy shows characteristic wide, ribbon-like aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles.

The below image shows biopsy findings seen in mucormycosis.

Treatment includes intravenous administration of amphotericin B and wide excision of necrotic tissues. Along with the reversal of underlying conditions and risk factors.

questions.text: A patient experienced two acute asthma exacerbations within one month despite ongoing therapy. Which of the following systemic steroids is suitable for her treatment?
questions.solution:
Prednisolone is a systemic steroid used for maintenance therapy after an acute exacerbation of asthma.

Intravenous corticosteroids such as hydrocortisone are indicated if the lung function is predicted to be <30% or if there's poor response to nebulized β2 agonists. After the exacerbation, oral predisolone can be substituted with maximal beneficial effect at 30-40mg daily.

Inhaled corticosteroids commonly used in asthma are:

  • Beclomethasone dipropionate
  • Budesonide
  • Ciclesonide
  • Fluticasone
  • Mometasone

questions.text: A 55-year-old man admitted with ischemic stroke was given IV alteplase. After 8 hours, the ICU staff noticed decreasing mental status and acute hypertension in the patient. A repeat CT revealed the following, Which of the following drugs can be used to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of post-thrombolytic hemorrhagic transformation of an ischemic stroke. ε-Aminocaproic acid can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic therapy.

It is a lysine analog that binds competitively to plasminogen, blocking plasminogen from binding to fibrin and the subsequent conversion to plasmin. This activity subsequently results in the inhibition of fibrinolysis.

It should not be given unless hemorrhage is life-threatening because it inhibits intrinsic fibrinolytic activity and can precipitate DIC. Fresh frozen plasma and cryoprecipitate may also be used to replenish fibrin and clotting factors.

questions.text: Angiography of the upper limb vessels showed blockage in the brachial artery. All of the following vessels will have decreased flow, except:
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the anterior circumflex humeral artery will have a normal blood supply. It is a branch of the axillary artery, not the brachial artery.

The brachial artery has 3 branches: 

  • Profunda brachii (accompanies radial nerve in the spiral groove) gives off nutrient artery to the humerus and an ascending branch which anastomoses with posterior circumflex humeral artery. It then divides into: 
    • Anterior descending artery (Radial collateral artery)  
    • Posterior descending artery (Middle collateral artery) 
  • Superior ulnar collateral artery (accompanies ulnar nerve)
  • Inferior ulnar collateral (Supratrochlear) artery

The image given below shows branches of brachial artery.

questions.text: What type of tympanogram is expected in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Image shows fluid in the middle ear, i.e., serous otitis media.

In such condition, compliance, i.e., ease of mobility of tympanic membrane decreases and hence resulting in a B curve. 

Fluid collection is usually secondary to negative middle ear pressure (Eustachian tube obstruction).

Tympanometry is an objective test of the middle ear and Eustachian tube functions (conductive compartment of hearing). Here, the compliance of the TM, i.e., how much it moves to the pressure differentials applied from the external ear is measured.

 

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A patient, 36 hours after cataract surgery, presents with complaints of pain and visual disturbance. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?

choices.text: Bandage and padding of the eye

questions.solution:
The image shows inflammation and hypopyon. These signs, along with the presentation of pain and visual disturbances acutely after cataract surgery, suggest that the patient has developed endophthalmitis. The management is to administer intravitreal antibiotics.

The majority of patients with postoperative endophthalmitis present with an acute onset and within seven days after surgery.

Endophthalmitis is defined as an intraocular inflammation, which predominantly affects the inner spaces of the eye and their contents, i.e., the vitreous and/or the anterior chamber.

The cardinal features of endophthalmitis are pain, swelling of the lid, and decrease in vision.

The patient classically presents with inflammation of the eye, corneal edema, and a hypopyon, due to the pouring of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.

Intravitreal injection of antibiotics has become the primary method of administration in the treatment of endophthalmitis. Systemic antibiotics have no role in the management of endophthalmitis. 

Other treatments:

  • Topical antibiotic
  • Cycloplegia
  • Oral steroids
  • Pars plana vitrectomy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the Vandematharam scheme?

choices.text: Its aim is to provide safe motherhood services
An MBBS graduate or an obstetrician can volunteer
IFA tablets and TT injections are provided by District Medical Officers

questions.solution:
The Vandematharam scheme does not include free treatment in private clinics.

Vandematharam scheme is a voluntary scheme for providing safe motherhood services. It can be volunteered by an obstetrician, maternity home, nursing home, lady doctor or an MBBS graduate.

IFA tablets, OCPs, and TT injections are provided by the respective District Medical Officers (DMOs) to the Vandematharam doctors or clinics for free distribution to beneficiaries. Cases needing special care and treatment can be referred to government hospitals.

11th of April is being observed as the National Safe Motherhood Day in India.

questions.text: A middle-aged man comes with complaints of sudden-onset chest pain radiating to the left arm and profuse sweating. An ECG taken showed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Which of the following is true regarding blood lactate dehydrogenase levels in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sudden onset chest pain with profuse sweating and ECG with ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF is suggestive of myocardial Infarction. Serum LDH 1 > LDH 2 levels are seen in this condition. 

Under normal conditions, LDH 2 is predominantly present in the blood and LDH 1 is predominantly present in the heart. So, normally LDH 2 > LDH 1 in blood. When cardiac tissue is damaged LDH 1 is released into the bloodstream. This results in a flipped lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) ratio where LDH 1 > LDH 2.

LDH is a tetrameric enzyme with 4 subunits. It has four subunits with two isoforms: H isoform (heart) and M isoform (muscle)

LDH Type  Composition Location
LDH-1 HHHH Heart and RBC
LDH-2 HHHM Heart and RBC
LDH-3 HHMM Lungs, brain, lymphatic tissues, and platelets
LDH-4 HMMM Liver and skeletal muscle
LDH-5 MMMM Liver and skeletal muscle

questions.text: Normal Reid index is ________
questions.solution:
Reid index is normally 0.4. It is defined as the ratio of the thickness of the submucosal gland layer to that of the bronchial wall.

It is increased in chronic bronchitis.
