questions.text: A patient with lung cancer was found to have the following finding on his anterior abdominal wall. On examination, you observe that the blood flow in these blood vessels is completely downwards. CT chest showed obstruction of a thoracic vessel. Which of the following is false about the same?

choices.text: Pierces the pericardium at 3rd costal cartilage
Enters the heart at the level of 4th intercostal space
Receives azygous vein below sternal angle

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of obstruction of the superior vena cava. It does not pierce the pericardium at the level of 3rd costal cartilage.

The superior vena cava pierces the pericardium opposite 2nd costal cartilage (angle of Louis/sternal angle), at the level of T4-T5 intervertebral disc. It also receives the azygous vein about 2 cm below the sternal plane at the level of T5 vertebra. 

It enters the right atrium at the level of the 4th intercostal space.

Superior vena cava syndrome:

Obstruction of superior vena cava due to metastatic cancers (eg. lung cancer, breast cancer, etc.) can result in reduced venous return from head and neck and upper extremities. It presents with swelling of the neck and face, dyspnea, headache, dizziness, and hemoptysis. Symptoms are aggravated by bending forwards.

On examination, the following may be seen

  • Dilated neck veins
  • Proptosis
  • Papilledema
  • Increased collateral veins on the anterior chest wall - flow is completely downward

CT-chest shows an absence or reduction of the opacification of the central veins and the presence of prominent collateral venous circulation.

 

Related Pearl: Angle of Louis

The angle of Loius (sternal angle) is formed by the manubriosternal joint at the level of 2nd costal cartilage anteriorly.

A plane joining the angle of Louis to the intervertebral disc between T4 and T5, called the sternal plane marks the following anatomical landmarks: 

  • Separates superior mediastinum form inferior mediastinum. 
  • Marks the position superior limit of pericardium.
  • Bifurcation of pulmonary trunk
  • Bifurcation of trachea (newer studies shows its lower)  
  • Origin of arch of aorta.
  • Site where superior venacava pierces the pericardium.

questions.text: The following slide is given as a spotter in your microbiology practical examination. Identify the following organism.
questions.solution:
The image shows pink non-branching acid-fast bacilli on a blue background. These findings are consistent with the staining characteristics of mycobacteria. The stain used is the Ziehl-Neelsen stain. 

Nocardia is partially acid-fast and appears as branching filaments.

Actinomyces and Corynebacterium are non-acid-fast.

The image below shows Nocardia stained using an acid fast staining technique.

 

The image given below is of a Gram stained specimen of Actinomyces israelii. 

 

The images below show the staining characteristics of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. 

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, M. avium, Nocardia etc.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: If the total body water is 60% of the body weight, what are the proportions of extracellular fluid (ECF) and intracellular fluid (ICF) respectively?
questions.solution:
When expressed as the percentage of body weight 20% of body weight is in ECF (1/3rd of 60%), and 40% of body weight is in ICF (2/3rd of 60%), 

The 60-40-20 rule is: 60% of body weight is water, of which 40% is ICF, and 20% is ECF.

Related Pearl: Body Fluids Compartments

  • In ECF, a third specialised compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. It constitutes <1% of TBW (1-2L).
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with headache, vomiting, amenorrhea, galactorrhea, loss of libido, and infertility. On examination, she has bitemporal hemianopia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms are suggestive of a local mass effect on the pituitary, increased intracranial pressure, and prolactinemia. The most likely diagnosis is a prolactinoma of the pituitary.

Prolactinoma

  • Prolactin-secreting lactotroph adenomas are the most frequent type of hyperfunctioning pituitary adenomas.
  • Females Males 
    Galactorrhoea

    galactorrhoea

    Gynecomastia
    Amenorrhoea or oligomenorrhoea Loss of libido
    Infertility

    Impotence 

    infertility
  • Serum prolactin concentrations tend to correlate with the size of the adenoma.
  •  

  • The normal range of serum prolactin is 5-20 μg/L. The diagnosis of prolactinoma is most likely to be associated with a prolactin level >200 μg/L.

     

Important points about pituitary adenomas

  • G ­protein mutations (particularly GNAS) are the most common genetic alterations seen in pituitary adenomas.
  • Pituitary adenomas are usually found in adults.
  • They may be functioning or non-functioning.
  • They are called microadenomas if they are <1 cm in diameter and macroadenomas if they are >1 cm in diameter.
  • Cellular monomorphism and the absence of a significant reticulin network distinguish pituitary adenomas from nonneoplastic anterior pituitary parenchyma.

Related Pearl: Classification of Pituitary Adenomas with Associated Syndromes

Prolactinoma (Lactotroph adenoma)

Galactorrhea and amenorrhea (in females)

Sexual dysfunction, infertility

GH secreting adenoma (Somatotroph adenoma)

Gigantism (children)

Acromegaly (adults)

Mammosomatotroph adenoma

Combined features of GH and prolactin excess

ACTH secreting adenoma (Corticotroph adenoma)

Cushing syndrome

Nelson syndrome

TSH secreting adenoma (Thyrotroph adenoma)

GH: Growth hormone

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone

TSH: Thyroid-stimulating hormone

Related Pearl: Cells of Anterior Pituitary

questions.text: Vogt‘s striae is seen in______.
questions.solution:
Vogt’s striae are the break in the Descemet’s membrane seen in keratoconus.

  • Very fine
  • Vertical, deep stromal striae
  • May disappear with external pressure on the globe.

Keratoconus (Conical cornea):

  • Degeneration of the cornea, which manifests after puberty
  • Conical protrusion of the cornea
  • There is myopia plus irregular astigmatism
  • Clinical features:
    • Diminished vision
    • Distant direct ophthalmoscopy shows a fairly well-delineated "oil droplet" reflex
    • Fleischer's ring: iron deposition on the epithelium
    • Munson’s Sign: V-shaped deformity of the lower lid on downward gaze
    • Scissoring reflex in retinoscopy
    • Prominent corneal nerve due to the thinning of the cornea

questions.text: While treating a patient with acute myocardial infarction, an abnormal rhythm was noted on the ECG. The senior resident decides to administer atropine to control this. What was the likely rhythm observed in the patient?
questions.solution:
Atropine is indicated in acute myocardial infarction when it is accompanied by sinus bradycardia due to excessive vagal tone. It is seen commonly in inferior or posterior wall myocardial infarction.

The dosage of atropine has to be carefully adjusted when used in a patient with myocardial infarction. If the dose is too low it will aggravate the bradycardia by action on presynaptic M1 receptors. If the dose is too high it will cause significant tachycardia and aggravate the condition by competitive inhibition of postsynaptic M2 receptors.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child has been posted for an adenoidectomy procedure. Which of the following conditions if present in this child will be a contraindication to performing the surgery?
questions.solution:
Cleft palate is a contraindication to perform adenoidectomy as removal of adenoids causes velopharyngeal insufficiency. 

Velopharyngeal insufficiency is a condition where the soft palate does not close tightly against the back of the throat. This leads to air coming out the nose (characterized by hypernasality) during speech. 

Contraindications for adenoidectomy:

  • Cleft palate or submucous palate. 
  • Hemorrhagic diathesis.
  • Acute infection of the upper respiratory tract.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.solution:
The fundus shows a pale waxy disc, attenuated arteries, and bony spicules, which implies retinitis pigmentosa (RP).  

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common. Among the hereditary type, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis.

The presenting feature is night blindness.

Investigations:

  • Perimetry- the initial stage will have ring scotoma, which further develops into tunnel vision.
  • Electroretinography- reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.

Atypical types of RP are as follows:

  • Sectoral RP
  • Pericentric/Inverse RP
  • RP sine pigmento
  • RP punctata albescens

There is no effective treatment for RP.

questions.text: Phases of the ventricular muscle action potential are shown below. At which phase of the below image is the action potential most dependant on sodium permeability?
questions.solution:
The action potential is most dependent on sodium permeability during phase 0. 

Action potential of the myocardium:

  • Phase 0: Depolarisation: Influx of Na+ into myocyte.
  • Phase 1: Early repolarization: Efflux of K+ from myocyte.
  • Phase 2: Plateau: Ca2+ enters myocardial cells via voltage-regulated L-type Ca2+ channels.
  • Phase 3: Repolarisation: Efflux of K+.
  • Phase 4: Restoration of RMP: Restoration of Na+ and K+ by Na-K ATPase.

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a physiological uncoupler?
questions.solution:
Thermogenin is a physiological uncoupler.

Uncouplers act by increasing the permeability of the mitochondrial membrane to ions. They collapse the proton gradient established by allowing the H+ to pass across the membrane without going through the ATP synthase enzyme complex.

  •  Synthetic: 2, 4 dinitrophenol
  •  Natural:Thyroxine and thermogenin. Thermogenin is found naturally in the brown adipose tissue, whose function is heat generation, especially in a newborn

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sesamoid bone?
questions.solution:
Os trigonum is an accessory bone, not a sesamoid bone. 

Accessory bones, also known as supernumerary bones are not always present. They may arise due to ununited epiphysis developed from extra ossification centres. Clinically, they may be mistaken for fractures. 

Examples of accessory bones

  • Os trigonum:  Uncommon accessory bone seen behind the talus. Also known as lateral tubercle of the talus.
  • Os vesalianum: Uncommon accessory bone located proximal to the fifth metatarsal and found within the peroneus brevis tendon. Also known as tuberosity of the fifth metatarsal.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with painless white eye with an intraocular pressure (IOP) of 60 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario, the diagnosis is suggestive of glaucomatocyclitic crisis.

Glaucomatocyclitic crisis (Posner–Schlossman Syndrome [PSS]):

  • Recurrent attacks of unilateral acute raised intraocular pressure (IOP) associated with mild anterior uveitis.
  • The mechanism is speculated to be acute trabeculitis, and there is evidence that infection, possibly cytomegalovirus (CMV) or Helicobacter pylori, may play a role.
  • PSS typically affects young to middle-aged adults. Males are affected more frequently than females.
  • Signs
    • Slit-lamp biomicroscopy typically shows a few anterior chamber cells and one to several fine white central keratic precipitates.
    • Mydriasis is common; posterior synechiae are not a feature.
    • IOP is typically raised to over 40 mmHg, out of proportion to iritis severity.
    • Gonioscopy shows an open-angle.
  • Treatment
    • Topical steroids are used to control inflammation, with aqueous suppressants to lower the IOP.
    • Topical or oral non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents may also be beneficial.

Other options : 

Option A: Chronic papilledema presents with a long history of recurrent transient blackouts, and visual blurring with normal IOP, and slit lamp examination.

Options B: Acute angle closure glaucoma presents with unilateral headache and dimension of vision with red eye due to massive congestion in the eye.

Option D: Acute anterior uveitis presents with photophobia, blurred vision, pain, ciliary congestion, tenderness, keratic precipitates, aqueous flare, and cells.

questions.text: An insured 35-year-old woman, who is working in a newspaper establishment, is undergoing a tubectomy procedure. According to the Employees State Insurance Act, she would receive the cash benefit under ____.
questions.solution:
Insured persons in the reproductive age group undergoing sterilization procedures such as tubectomy and vasectomy are offered cash benefit under the ESI Act as enhanced sickness benefit. 

The enhanced sickness benefit equal to full wage is payable to insured persons undergoing sterilization. 7 days for male workers, post-vasectomy, and 14 days for female workers, post-tubectomy.

Other options: 

Option B: Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.

Option C: Maternity Benefit – the benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman

Option D: Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with complaints of dysphagia and chest pain. A barium swallow is performed and shows the following finding. Which of the following could be a cause of the condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium swallow showing the bird-beak appearance is suggestive of achalasia cardia. Secondary achalasia may arise in Chagas disease, which is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi infection.

The infection causes the destruction of the myenteric plexus, failure of peristalsis, and esophageal dilatation.

Duodenal, colonic, and ureteric myenteric plexuses can also be affected by Chagas disease.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus.

Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.

Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease

Clinical features:

  • dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • regurgitation
  • chest pain
  • weight loss
  • bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, Chagas’ disease, and pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation and Heller myotomy

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy complains of intense lacrimation, associated with photophobia. On further examination, the following finding is seen in his upper tarsal conjunctiva. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts cobblestone appearance, which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). No follicular reaction is seen.

  • Vernal conjunctivitis is also called as spring catarrh or warm weather conjunctivitis
  • It primarily affects boys, and the onset is generally from the age of 5 years.
  • It is primarily a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction that is IgE mediated. It also involves type 4 hypersensitivity reaction.

Classical features of conjunctiva in VKC:

Palpebral VKC

  • Cobblestone papillae: upper tarsal conjunctiva
  • Associated with ropy discharge
  • Maxwell–Lyon sign: pseudomembrane formation of the upper lid when everted and exposed to heat 

Limbal VKC: Horner–Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris in the limbal area. 

Corneal signs in VKC:

  • Shield ulcers
  • Vernal plaques
  • Subepithelial scarring
  • Pseudo-gerontoxon resembles arcus senilus; it has a cupid's bow outline

Image: Horner Trantas spots

Other options :

Option a : In acute trachoma, sago-like follicles are characteristically seen. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The SAFE strategy is used in the management of trachoma.

The image below shows sago-like follicles in trachoma.
 

option c : In Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is associated with, white-pinkish nodule in the bulbar conjunctiva.

Option d :  Xerophthalmia is associated with epithelial xerosis and bitot spot in bulbar conjunctiva.

questions.text: The main excitatory and inhibitory neurotransmitters in the CNS are ______
questions.solution:
Glutamate is the main excitatory neurotransmitter in the CNS. It is responsible for 75% of the excitatory transmission in the brain.

Glycine and GABA are the main inhibitory neurotransmitters in the CNS. Glycine is the main inhibitory neurotransmitter in the spinal cord. GABA is the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive woman visits the clinic with complaints of memory loss. CD4 count done at that time showed it was 50. A couple of months later, the patient dies and autopsy of the brain showed demyelination. The most likely co-infection was?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario of HIV patient with low CD4 count, complaints of memory loss, and demyelination on autopsy, the disease is progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy(PML) caused by JC virus.

PML is a fatal subacute progressive demyelinating disease caused by the neurotrophic JC polyomavirus. It is an opportunistic infection that usually occurs at CD4 counts less than 200 per microliter.

The image below shows brain biopsy of a Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy case showing Oligodendrocytes with SV40 positive inclusions indicative of JC Virus infection (SV40 Immunohistochemistry, brown)

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasms found in patients with HIV infection

Infections

  • Protozoal and Helminthic Infections
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal Infections
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial Infections
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral Infections
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

 

One-liners about HIV

  • Sexual contact is the least efficacious yet most common mode of spread of HIV infection
  • ELISA is used for the detection of antibodies against viral proteins. This is the most sensitive and the best screening test for the diagnosis of AIDS.
  • Western blot is the most specific or the confirmatory test for HIV.
  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection in patients with AIDS.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) chorioretinitis exclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.
  • Toxoplasma gondii causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.
  • John Cunningham virus (JC virus) is a human papovavirus that causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • Persistent diarrhea in AIDS is caused by Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli, or microsporidia.
  • AIDS-dementia complex is the most common neurological manifestation of HIV infection.
  • Inflammatory myopathy is the commonest skeletal muscle disorder in HIV.

questions.text: A patient was referred by a doctor to a tertiary center for a PET scan and the doctor was given money for the referral. What is this unethical act called?
questions.solution:
This unethical act of receiving a commission for referring a patient is referred to as Dichotomy. 

Dichotomy is an unethical act wherein a doctor receives a gift, commission or money for referring, recommending, or procuring a patient for any medical, surgical or other treatments. Fee splitting is unethical in India.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, in the first trimester of pregnancy from a tribal area, presented with fever and chills for the last 3 days. After examination of the peripheral smear given below, chloroquine was started but there was no improvement in the patient's condition. Which of the following is preferred for treating this patient?
questions.solution:
Quinine plus clindamycin is preferred for the treatment of chloroquine-resistant falciparum malaria in the 1st trimester of pregnancy.

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a chloroquine-resistant malarial infection. The image given shows ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocytes, which are binucleate (double chromatin) and resemble stereo headphones in appearance, characteristic of malaria caused by P. falciparum. 

Worldwide most infections with P. falciparum malaria are resistant to chloroquine. In the 1st trimester, pregnant women diagnosed with uncomplicated malaria caused by chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum infection, the drug of choice is a combination of quinine and clindamycin. Artemisinin-based combination therapy can be used as an alternative for patients that are unable to tolerate oral quinine.

In the second and third trimesters, they can be treated with artemisinin combination therapy such as:

  • Artemether-lumefantrine
  • Artesunate-amodiaquine
  • Artesunate-mefloquine
  • Dihydroartemisinin-piperaquine
  • Artesunate + clindamycin

During pregnancy, P. vivax malaria is treated with chloroquine as it is safe in pregnancy and children. In chloroquine-resistant vivax cases, clindamycin, quinine, chloroquine, and proguanil can be used.

Other options:

Option B: Doxycycline is useful in the treatment of malaria but not used in pregnancy.

Options C: Artemether plus lumefantrine is not the drug of choice in the 1st trimester of pregnancy. ACT may be given in the first trimester only if oral quinine is not tolerated or not available.

Option D: ACT with pyrimethamine-sulfadoxine is avoided in the first trimester.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely in a patient with cyanosis?
questions.solution:
In stagnant hypoxia, blood flow is very low; so, more oxygen is extracted causing an increase in reduced hemoglobin → cyanosis.

Cyanosis - Cyanosis is the dusky bluish discoloration of the tissues occurring when the reduced hemoglobin concentration is more than 5g/dL.

  • Its occurrence depends upon
    • The total amount of hemoglobin in the blood
    • Degree of hemoglobin unsaturation
    • The state of capillary circulation

Option a: In the case of anemia, the total hemoglobin content is low, so enough reduced hemoglobin cannot be formed.

Option b: In histotoxic hypoxia, the amount of reduced hemoglobin formed is very less because the defect is in the tissue O2.

Option c: In CO poisoning, there is the formation of carboxyhemoglobin, which is red in color obscure the color of reduced hemoglobin.

questions.text: A patient who underwent skull base surgery developed drooping of the left side of his face and loss of taste sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, the general sensation over the tongue is intact. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of damage to the facial nerve above the level of the stylomastoid foramen, resulting in injury to chorda tympani nerve.

Taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by chorda tympani nerve, whereas general sensation is carried by the lingual nerve.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with a history of sharing needles during IV drug abuse with an HIV-positive partner. HIV-antibody spot test was negative, however p24 antigen assay was positive. You explain to him that he is currently in the window period for HIV. Which of the following statements would you use to explain the concept to him?

choices.text: It is the time period between infection and onset of first symptoms
It is the time period between infection and detection of antibodies
It is the time period between exposure and onset of viral multiplication
It is the time period between exposure and appearance of symptoms

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has experienced a high-risk exposure to HIV due to sharing needles during IV drug abuse with an HIV-positive partner. 

The period between infection and detection of antibodies against HIV is known as the window period.

The window period may last anywhere between 2–8 weeks to a few months. During this period, the individual may be highly infectious. HIV infection can be detected during this period by p24 antigen assay and PCR.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with the finding shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image provided is characteristic of Casal's necklace, seen in pellagra, and indicates a deficiency of Tryptophan.

Pellagra can occur due to:

  • Vitamin B3 (niacin)
    • Niacin is derived from tryptophan and needs B2 and B6 for its synthesis.
  • Hartnup's disease (tryptophan malabsorption)
  • Malignant carcinoid syndrome (↑ tryptophan metabolism)
  • Isoniazid (↓ vitamin B6)

In Hartnup's disease, defective membrane transport of tryptophan across PCT and enterocytes leads to malabsorption of tryptophan. This causes a deficiency of tryptophan.

As a result, the production of niacin from tryptophan is reduced and this manifests as pellagra with dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia (3D's), and glossitis. A characteristic skin rash called the Casal’s necklace may also be seen.

Related Pearl: Conditions Associated with Pellagra-like Symptoms

Intestinal & renal malabsorption of tryptophan

Carcinoid syndrome

Overproduction of serotonin that causes diversion of  tryptophan from NAD+ Pathway

Vitamin B6 deficiency

Defective kynureninase pathway

Maize rich diet

Niacin is in unavailable niacytin form

Jowar diet (Sorghum)

questions.text: Spermatogenesis is maintained by which hormone?
questions.solution:
All three of them (testosterone, FSH, LH) are required for spermatogenesis.

Pulses of hypothalamic GnRH stimulate the anterior pituitary to secrete FSH and LH, which then act on the testes

FSH acts on the Sertoli cells to stimulate spermatogenesis and inhibin secretion. LH acts on the Leydig cells to stimulate testosterone secretion. Testosterone, acting locally on the Sertoli cells, is essential for maintaining spermatogenesis.

questions.text: A single mutation in a nucleotide base pair resulting in a termination codon is known as?
questions.solution:
A single mutation in a nucleotide base pair resulting in a termination codon is called a nonsense mutation.

Other options

Option A: Missense mutation is a single mutation in a nucleotide resulting in the production of a different amino acid.

Option C: When 2 or 3 nucleotides are deleted, a drastically different amino acid or a truncated product may be formed. This is termed a frameshift mutation.

Option D: If the codon containing the changed base codes for the same amino acid, it is termed as a silent mutation.

questions.text: A patient presented the clinical finding shown in the image. His showed serum cholesterol is 283 mg/dL and his serum LDL is 202 mg/dL. His triglyceride levels are within normal limits. Which of the following is most likely defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with tendon xanthomas and elevated serum LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and elevated serum cholesterol points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia(FH)(type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia). This is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors and Apo B100.

This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk of developing atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Features of FH: 

  • Painful polyarthritis and tendinitis are common.
  • Physical findings seen are corneal arcus and tendon xanthomas over the Achilles tendon and the dorsum of the hands. Xanthomas are tumorous masses produced by foamy cell clusters (lipid-laden macrophages) found in the connective tissue of the skin and in tendons.

Diagnosis is done clinically based on hypercholesterolemia with 

  • LDL >190 mg/dl, 
  • Family history of hypercholesterolemia and/or
  • Premature coronary artery disease.

Treatment includes lifestyle changes, restriction of a fatty diet, and pharmacotherapy with statins.

Recent drugs for the specific treatment of homozygous FH are:

  • Lomitapide, a microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) inhibitor, and
  • Mipomersen, an antisense oligonucleotide against apoB.

 A plain lateral radiograph of both ankles shows bilateral symmetrical swellings (arrows) superior to the calcaneum.

Patients can also have yellowish plaques around the eyes (Xanthelasma) and corneal arcus.

Other options

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. There is an increased risk of atherosclerosis.

The image below shows enlarged yellow-orange colored tonsils in Tangier's disease.

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes type I hyperlipoproteinemia due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk of coronary disease. Instead, patients have an increased risk of acute pancreatitis. This is due to very high triglyceride levels. It can also cause a milky appearance of plasma.

 

Option D: Acid lipase deficiency can lead to Wolman's disease which is a lysosomal storage disease. The pathognomic feature of this condition is adrenal calcification. Patients are generally neonates who present with adrenal insufficiency.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, TG and cholesterol Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: In a case of suspected homicide, the wife has been arrested for allegedly shooting the husband. She was found to be guilty based on the presence of gunpowder residue on her hands. Which of the following tests is the most sensitive for detection of gunpowder residue?

choices.text: Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy
Scanning Electron Microscopy with Energy Dispersive X-ray Analysis

questions.solution:
Scanning Electron Microscopy with Energy Dispersive X-ray Analysis is the most sensitive test for detection of gunshot residue(GSRs).

Tests for detection of gunpowder residue

  • Dermal nitrate (paraffin) test
  • Harrison and Gilroy test
  • Neutron Activation Analysis (NAA)
  • Flameless Atomic Absorption Spectroscopy (FAAS)
  • Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) - a variant of Flameless Atomic Absorption Spectroscopy
  • Scanning Electron Microscopy with Energy Dispersive X-ray Analysis (SEM -EDX)

The most commonly used method for detection of gunshot residue is scanning electron microscopy–energy-dispersive x-ray spectrometry (SEM–EDX).

questions.text: A young patient was managed with the following cast for a closed fracture of the leg. The patient also had a few abrasions over the ankle. According to biomedical waste management, this cast should be disposed of in which of the following bins?

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in strenuous exercise?

choices.text: Right shift of O2-Hb dissociation curve

questions.solution:
Strenuous exercise can cause hyperkalemia by releasing potassium from skeletal muscle.

NOTE: Exercise leads to release of endogenous opiods and is associated with mood enhancement.

questions.text: The nerve supply of the perineum is _______
questions.solution:
The nerve supply of the perineum is by the pudendal nerve.

Nerve Origin Course Distribution

questions.text: Which part of middle ear is formed by tegmen tympani?

It separates the tympanic cavity from the middle cranial fossa.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man who is a chronic alcoholic has the following hepatitis B profile:
HBs Ag positive, HBe Ag positive, declining IgM anti-HBc in the presence of rising total anti-HBc.
What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this case is chronic infective hepatitis.

HBsAg positive suggests active infection.

HBeAg positive signifies continued viral replication, high infectivity, and probable progression to chronic hepatitis.

Declining IgM anti-HBc in the presence of rising total anti-HBc indicates IgM being converted to IgG and hence the infection is chronic.

questions.text: A 9 year old child was diagnosed with acute coalescent mastoiditis. Examination reveals collection of pus under the sheath of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. What is the most likely complication that occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with acute coalescent mastoiditis, most likely has Bezold's abscess.

Bezold's abscess is one of the main complications of acute coalescent mastoiditis and is formed when pus breaks inferiorly, through the thin medial aspect of the tip of the mastoid and collects in the upper part of the neck, most commonly into the sheath of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

The abscess can also take any of the following locations: 

  • Deep to the sternocleidomastoid
  • Along the posterior belly of the digastric presenting as a swelling in the tip of the mastoid or the angle of the jaw
  • The upper part of the posterior triangle
  • Parapharyngeal space
  • Along with the carotid vessels.

Treatment:

  1. Cortical mastoidectomy for coalescent mastoiditis
  2. Drainage of the abscess in the neck with insertion of a drain through a separate incision
  3. IV antibiotics

Other options:

Option A: Zygomatic abscess forms due to infection of the zygomatic air cells. It is situated at the posterior root of the zygoma.  Patients present with swelling in front and above the pinna with associated edema over the upper eyelid. Here the pus collects either superficial or deep to the temporalis muscle.

Option C: Luc abscess is defined as a subperiosteal temporal abscess. It develops following the spread of infection from the middle ear along the external auditory meatus, directly, to the temporal region. Swelling is present in the deep part of the bony meatus. 

Option D: Citelli’s abscess is formed posterior to the mastoid, occupying a position more towards the occipital bone. It is also considered an abscess of the digastric triangle. In any case, a diagnosis of Bezold abscess is more appropriate for this patient owing to the location of the abscess.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male came to the hospital with complaints of headache and visual impairment. On CT, a calcified mass was found in the suprasellar region and a diagnosis of craniopharyngioma was made. What type of visual field defect is likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect usually found in craniopharyngioma is bitemporal hemianopia.

Lesions of the optic chiasma can cause bitemporal hemianopia.i.e, loss of vision in the temporal halves of both visual fields. Nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma at this level and hence, these fibers are compromised.

Other causes of chiasmal lesions are

  • Pituitary adenoma (most common)
  • Suprasellar tumours- Craniopharyngiomas, meningiomas
  • Gliomas of the third ventricle
  • Dermoid tumours
  • Pinealomas

Craniopharyngiomas are benign masses usually presenting in the suprasellar region arising near the pituitary stalk and can produce functional impairment of the hypophysis due to mass effect. The clinical features of craniopharyngiomas include headaches,visual field defects,growth failure and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypofunction. CT scan may show calcifications in the supra-sellar region. Treatment includes transcranial or transsphenoidal surgical resection followed by postoperative radiation.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Identify the type of cartilage shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The above image shows an elastic cartilage.

The elastic cartilage, like the hyaline cartilage, contains individual or small groups of chondrocytes that are surrounded by type II collagen fibrils. However, it differs from hyaline cartilage in that, much of the interterritorial matrix consists of fine yellow elastic fibres containing elastin protein.

On microscopy, elastic cartilage consists of:

  • Elastic fibres in the matrix
  • Perichondrium with outer fibrous layer and the inner cellular layer

questions.text: A patient has been on lisinopril since being diagnosed with hypertension last year. His blood pressure readings are quite high, and the doctor considers adding a diuretic. Which amongst the following would be the ideal add on drug?
questions.solution:
Hydrochlorothiazide would be the ideal add-on drug. It is a thiazide diuretic and causes hypokalemia, which can counteract the hyperkalemia caused by lisinopril, an ACE inhibitor.

Aldosterone causes Na+ absorption in the collecting duct and the distal tubule in exchange for H+ and K+. ACE inhibitors decrease angiotensin II levels and thereby, decrease aldosterone levels. Decreased aldosterone level causes K+ retention by reducing the exchange. Therefore, ACE inhibitors cause retention of K+.

Diuretics that cause elevation of plasma K+ levels are not suitable for combining with ACE inhibitors.

Potassium-sparing diuretics like spironolactone, eplerenone, and amiloride are contraindicated with ACE inhibitors.

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presents with sudden bilateral swelling of lower limbs associated with diarrhea, dyspnea, and signs of cardiac failure. Mustard oil adulteration is suspected to be the cause. What is the toxin involved?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic dropsy. It is caused by the toxic compound sanguinarine, which is present in argemone oil extracted from argemone seeds. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure.

Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography - most sensitive test
  • Nitric acid test

questions.text: The pressure-volume curve is shifted to the left in:
questions.solution:
The pressure-volume curve is shifted to the left in mitral stenosis.

The PV loop is shifted to the right when there is volume overload (increased end-diastolic volume).
The PV loop is shifted to the left in case of increased contractility or decreased compliance (decreased end-diastolic volume).

Effect of valvular diseases on PV loop:

  • Mitral stenosis: Left and down.
  • Mitral regurgitation: Width increased and height decreased.
  • Aortic stenosis: Tall with steep slope.
  • Aortic regurgitation: Right and tall.

questions.text:
Match the following with their rate-limiting enzymes:
1- Heme synthesis a- HMG CoA reductase
2- Cholesterol synthesis b- Phosphofructokinase
3- Glycolysis c- ALA synthase
4- Niacin synthesis d- HMG CoA synthase
  e- Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-e.

Heme synthesis ALA synthase
Cholesterol synthesis HMG CoA reductase
Glycolysis Phosphofructokinase
Niacin syntheses Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase

Heme is synthesized in the normoblasts except matures erythrocytes. Heme synthesis is partly mitochondrial and partly cytoplasmic. It starts with the condensation of succinyl CoA and glycine by ALA synthase in the presence of pyridoxal phosphate to form delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA). ALA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme and is located in mitochondria. 

All nucleated cells including the arterial wall can synthesize cholesterol and the liver, adrenal cortex, testis, ovaries, and intestines are the major sites of cholesterol synthesis. It occurs partly in the endoplasmic reticulum and cytoplasm. it starts with the condensation of two molecules of acetyl CoA to form acetoacetyl CoA synthase. 

The reduction of HMG CoA to mevalonate catalyzed by HMG CoA reductase is the rate-limiting step. it is the rate-limiting enzyme and is located in the endoplasmic reticulum. 

Statin group of drugs like lovastatin are competitive inhibitors of HMG CoA reductase and can be used in clinical practice to reduce cholesterol levels in the blood. 

Glycolysis converts glucose to pyruvate (aerobic condition) or lactate (anaerobic condition) with the production of a small quantity of energy. It takes place in all cells of the body. Phosphofructokinase is the rate-limiting enzyme that converts fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1-6-bisphosphate.

The rate-limiting enzyme of synthesis of niacin from tryptophan is quinolinate phosphoribosyltransferase. It converts niacin or nicotinic acid to nicotinate mononucelotide.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man was brought to the casualty by the local police after they found him lying in a roadside drain. On examination, his speech was slurred and he was unable to recall any of the events that happened in the past 2 hours. His serum alcohol level was 260 mg/dl. His cognitive deficits can be attributed to the action of alcohol on which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes a case of an alcoholic blackout. NMDA receptor is implicated in many aspects of cognitive function including learning and memory. 

"Blackouts" are periods of anterograde memory loss that occur due to alcohol intoxication when the blood level of alcohol is between 200-300 mg/dl. It is due to the inhibition of the action of glutamate on NMDA receptors.  

Impairment likely to be seen at various blood alcohol levels is shown below: 

Level (mg/dL) Impairment

20–30

30–80  Increase in motor and cognitive problems
80–200 

Increase in incoordination and judgment errors

Mood lability

Deterioration in cognition
200–300 

Nystagmus

Marked slurring of speech

Alcoholic blackouts
>300  Impaired vital signs and possible death

questions.text: A Ph.D. scholar is preparing to do a prospective cohort study for the association of H. pylori with IBD from the gastroenterology wards. Which of the following must she do?

choices.text: Enrol all patients taking proton pump inhibitor
Enrol all patients on whom endoscopy was done
Exclude all patients with diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease
Exclude all patients with positive urea breath test for H. pylori

questions.solution: Cohort studies progress from cause to effect. Thus, the patients with IBD must be excluded. The study begins before the disease under study has occurred.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with complaints of fatigue. She is a known case of type 2 diabetes mellitus on treatment. On examination, there is pallor and knuckle pigmentation. Which of the following drugs could have caused her condition?
questions.solution:
Metformin can cause vitamin B12 deficiency which manifests as megaloblastic anemia (pallor, fatigue) with knuckle pigmentation.

The most common side effect of metformin is GI intolerance as nausea, bloating, abdominal cramps and diarrhoea.

Note: The exact reason why metformin causes vitamin B12 deficiency is not known. 

The proposed mechanisms include:

  • Alterations in small bowel motility, which stimulates bacterial overgrowth and consequential vitamin B12 deficiency
  • Competitive inhibition or inactivation of vitamin B12 absorption
  • Alterations in intrinsic factor (IF) levels and interaction with the cubilin endocytic receptor.
  • Inhibition of the calcium-dependent absorption of the vitamin B12-IF complex at the terminal ileum.

questions.text: The maternal mortality rate is expressed as "number of maternal deaths in a given period per ____ during the same time period".
questions.solution:
The maternal mortality rate is expressed as the "number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 women in reproductive age during the same time period".

Note: The maternal mortality ratio is expressed as the "number of maternal deaths during a given period per 100,000 live births during the same time period".

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Crude death rate = ( Number of deaths during the year/Mid year population ) x 1000

Age specific death rate = ( Number of deaths in specific age groups/Mid year population of that age group ) x 1000

Sex specific death rate = ( Number of deaths per year of that sex/Mid year population of that sex ) x 1000

Case fatality rate = ( Total number of deaths due to a particular disease/Total number of cases due to same disease ) x 100

Proportional mortality from a particular disease = ( Number of deaths from a specific disease in a year/ Total deaths from all causes in a year ) x 100

Under 5 mortality rate = ( Number of deaths under 5 yrs of age in a year/Total live birth in that year ) x 1000

Survival rate = ( Total number of patients alive after 5 yrs /Total number of patients diagnosed or treated ) x 100

questions.text: Which of the following study designs is used to estimate relative risk (RR)?
questions.solution:
Relative risk is best estimated in cohort studies.

Relative Risk:

  • The ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called the risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR >1 indicates a positive association.
  • RR of 2 or higher indicates a >/=100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ c/(c+d)] where, 
  Disease
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

questions.text: All the passengers coming to India were screened for COVID-19 at the airport. Which type of screening is done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The type of screening done for the immigrants to a country is prospective screening. 

Prospective screening is done for disease control. People are examined for the benefit of others. It may lead to an early diagnosis and permit more effective treatment. It also reduces the spread of infectious diseases in the community, thereby reducing the mortality associated with the disease.

Other examples of prospective screening:

  • Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the home population.
  • Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever.

Other options:

Option A: Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are examined for their own benefit. Screening is initiated by medical and public health personnel and is not requested by a patient. It may lead to an early diagnosis of an unrecognized disease. Hence, appropriate treatment can be initiated immediately to arrest disease progression.

Examples of prescriptive screening:

  • Screening of infants for phenylketonuria
  • Screening of school children for visual and auditory defects.

Option B: Multiphasic screening is the combined application of two or more screening tests to a large number of people at one time. It is not cost-effective and has shown no benefit in reducing the morbidity and mortality of the population. Examples include a pregnant woman undergoing various screening tests (VDRL, HIV, HBV, etc) at a time.

Option D: Selective screening is done in high-risk groups. It is one of the most productive screening tests. Examples include MRI screening of the breast done annually in a 25-year-old woman with a first-degree relative having BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation.

questions.text: A middle-aged man has been recently diagnosed with hypertension. He wants to try lifestyle changes before starting with pharmacological therapy. According to the rule of halves, where is he represented in the diagram, if A represents the whole population?
questions.solution:
According to the rule of halves, the person is represented in category C which represents people diagnosed with hypertension but not treated. This is because the patient has not yet started lifestyle management or pharmacotherapy.

Hypertension is a non-communicable chronic condition that is a risk factor for coronary heart disease, stroke, and other vascular complications. It is known to be an iceberg disease and the rule of halves is applied. The rule depicts the disease burden of hypertension in the community.

It states that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population are aware of the condition. Only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

Pictorial representation of the rule of halves in hypertension is shown below:

 

Hypertension can be prevented by primary and secondary prevention strategies. Primary prevention includes non-pharmacological measures such as lifestyle changes that are taken to reduce the incidence of the disease. It includes:

  • Population strategy approach aimed to reduce the incidence of the disease at the whole population level
  • High-risk strategy approach is done to identify high-risk individuals 

Secondary prevention includes pharmacological measures such as the usage of antihypertensives in affected individuals. It aims at early detection, adequate treatment, and follow-up of the patients to ensure proper compliance.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother with complaints of biting his lips and nails. On examination, the child has delayed developmental milestones, spasticity, and dystonia. Nail findings are as shown in the image below. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated uric acid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image showing self-mutilation and laboratory values showing hyperuricemia is most likely suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan disease.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to a complete deficiency of the hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine leading to increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP). Increased PRPP leads to increased purine synthesis, which is later degraded to uric acid. Increased hypoxanthine is also converted to uric acid.

The patients have intellectual disability, behaviors of self-injury like lip and finger biting, developmental delay, muscle dystonia, and extrapyramidal symptoms. 

Diagnosis is made by the elevated levels of uric acid and by HGPRT enzyme assay.

The image given below shows the metabolism of hypoxanthine and guanine by HGPRT.

Other options:

Option A: Autism mainly presents with problems in social communication and social interaction. They have poor verbal and non-verbal communication, absence of eye contact, repetitive behaviors like lining up toys or flipping objects, echolalia, etc. Intellectual impairment may or may not be present.

Option C: Patients with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) present with infections. Diarrhea, pneumonia, otitis media, sepsis, and cutaneous infections are common presentations. It is caused by various genetic mutations that lead to the absence of T and B-cell function. They have a low lymphocyte count.

Option D: Tourette’s disorder is characterized by sudden repetitive, non-rhythmic motor movements or sounds. They present with loud grunting or barking noises or shouting obscene words. Motor tics include tongue protrusion, sniffing, hopping, squatting, blinking, or nodding.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is likely to be most abundant in collagen?
questions.solution:
The most abundant amino acid in collagen is glycine.

Collagen is the most abundant protein in the animal world. It consists of three alpha chains held together by hydrogen bonds forming a triple helical structure.

A striking characteristic of collagen is the occurrence of glycine residues at every third position, (Gly-X-Y) repeats.

Proline and hydroxyproline confer rigidity on the collagen molecule. Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are formed by the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues. This hydroxylation is catalyzed by the enzyme prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase, and cofactors are ascorbic acid (vitamin C) and α-ketoglutarate.

Intracellular steps in the synthesis of collagen:

  • Signal peptide cleavage
  • Hydroxylation of prolyl residues and some lysyl residues, glycosylation of some hydroxylysyl residues
  • Intrachain and interchain S–S bonds formation in extension peptides
  • Triple helix formation

Extracellular steps in the synthesis of collagen:

  • Amino- and carboxyl-terminal propeptides cleavage
  • Collagen fibers assembly in quarter-staggered alignment
  • Oxidative deamination of h -amino groups of lysyl and hydroxylysyl residues to aldehydes
  • Intra- and interchain cross-links formation via Schiff bases and aldol condensation products

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: The antiemetic action of metoclopramide is primarily due to which of the following actions?
questions.solution:
The antiemetic action of metoclopramide is primarily due to D2 antagonism in the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ)

Metoclopramide has both antiemetic and prokinetic action. Peripheral D2 antagonism and 5HT4 agonism contribute to the prokinetic action. 

Metoclopramide includes the following action:

  • 5HT4 receptor agonism
  • 5HT3 receptor antagonism
  • D2 antagonism
  • Sensitization of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscles

questions.text: CSF rhinorrhea is seen in all except_______
questions.solution:
CSF rhinorrhea is seen in naso-orbito-ethmoid fracture, Le-Fort II & III but not in Le-Fort I which is transverse fracture of maxilla.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

Others:

  • Cisapride
  • Sumatriptan
  • Zolmitriptan
  • Arsenic
  • Dolasetron
  • Methadone

questions.text: Name the principle of the test shown below:
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a Duochrome test based on chromatic aberration. It is used to refine the final sphere in subjective refraction.

  • The patient is asked to compare the clarity of the letters on the green and the red side.
  • If a myopic sees the letters of the green side clearer, he is overcorrected. So, +0.25 D sphere is added or -0.25D is removed.
  • However, if a myopic sees the letters on the red side clearer, he is undercorrected and -0.25 D sphere is added.
  • With optimal spherical correction, the letters on the red and green halves of the chart appear equally clear.

questions.text: In the SRK formula for intraocular lens power calculation 'E=A-2.5L-0.9K', the value of L is estimated using__________
questions.solution:
The value of L, which is the axial length of the eyeball is calculated using the A-scan ultrasonographic biometry

 The most widely used formula for intraocular lens power calculation is the Sanders-Retzlaff-Kraff formula, given by

 E = A - 2.5L - 0.9K

Where E is the emmetropic power designated for the eye 

  • A is a constant which is specific for each lens type.
  • L is the axial length of eyeball in mm determined using the "A" scan ultrasonography.
  • K is the average corneal curvature, which is determined by keratometry.

questions.text: A study compares the body weights of a group of individuals before and after putting them on a special diet. Which of the following tests is used in this case?
questions.solution:
This study involves a quantitative variable, i.e, body weight, and compares the before and after results of the same group. Hence, paired T-test is used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: The image shown below represents which type of mechanical asphyxia?
questions.solution:
The type of strangulation shown in the image is Burking. 

Burking is a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter throws the victim to the ground and kneels or sits on the chest of the victim preventing chest movements. He/she then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his/her hands. 

Other options:

Option A: Mugging is a type of strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the crook of the elbow.  Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm. In mugging, the attack is usually made from behind.

The below image show strangulation by mugging.

Option B: Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown around the unaware victim’s neck and then tightened by twisting it with a lever such as a rod or stick within the ligature. Earlier in Spain, garroting was an official method of judicial execution.

Option D: In bansdola, one strong bamboo or stick is placed across the back of the neck and another across the front. The victim is squeezed to death by tieing both ends of the stick with rope.

On examination, a bruise can be seen in the centre of the neck across the windpipe corresponding to the width of the stick or the substance used. A similar mark can be seen on the back of the neck if two sticks are used.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pilot with low back pain requires a painkiller that is effective at once-daily dosing. You decide to prescribe the NSAID with the longest plasma half-life. Which drug will you choose?
questions.solution:
Piroxicam is chosen as it has the longest plasma half-life among NSAIDs.

Piroxicam is absorbed completely and undergoes enterohepatic circulation. Due to the long half-life, once-daily administration of the drug is sufficient for the therapeutic response.

questions.text: A gardener from the sub-Himalayan region presents with the multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along the lymphatics. The tissue biopsy was done and sent to the laboratory for culture. On microscopy, the flower-like clusters of conidia as shown in the image below are seen. The most common fungus responsible for this condition is _____
questions.solution:
The presence of multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along lymphatics in a gardener from the sub-Himalayan region and the microscopic finding of flower-like clusters of conidia are suggestive of sporotrichosis. The most common fungus responsible for this condition is Sporothrix schenckii.

Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous disease, by traumatic inoculation into the skin. This is a chronic infection involving cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue. It usually follows spreads along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes.

The initial infection develops as a nodule, which may break down to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. Untreated, the disease progresses and new nodules develop along the lymphatics leading to a chain of nodules.

Less commonly it may also cause systemic infection following inhalation, which causes local pulmonary disease or may lead to widely disseminated lesions in joints, meninges, and skin.

Laboratory diagnosis includes direct microscopic examination of necrotic material in KOH mount or histopathological examination of tissue sections stained by methenamine silver stain showing the asteroid body. Asteroid body is a rounded or oval, basophilic, yeast-like body 3-5 μmin diameter, with rays of an eosinophilic substance radiating from the yeast cell.

Image showing asteroid body:

Treatment: Itraconazole is the drug of choice for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.
